raw_text:
Galloway plea for hostage release
 
 Ex-Labour MP George Galloway has appealed for the release of aid worker Margaret Hassan, kidnapped in Iraq.
 
 Mrs Hassan, 59, who led Care International operations in Iraq, was abducted in Baghdad on 19 October. Mr Galloway was expelled from the Labour party because of his staunch opposition to the war on Iraq. He denied an earlier report that he planned to make a direct appeal to the kidnappers via the Al-Jazeera Arabic television channel.
 
 Speaking in London on Saturday at the first annual delegate conference of his newly-founded party, the Respect Coalition, he said: "I have deliberately not involved myself before in any of these situations. "But this woman has been a prominent opponent of both the war and the preceding years of sanctions. "I am prepared to do anything I can to help save her life." A spokesman later said Mr Galloway had friends in common with Ms Hassan, who he described as a prominent anti-war activist, and that he was "willing to do anything - go to Iraq or be an intermediary or anything that's necessary". Since her abduction, several videos of Mrs Hassan have been broadcast by Al-Jazeera. The latest footage showed Mrs Hassan asking for British troops to be pulled out of Iraq. She also urged Care International, the aid agency she works for, to close its office in Baghdad, and appealed for Iraqi women prisoners to be freed. Care has since closed down all its operations in Iraq.
llama3.2:1b: George Galloway appeals for Margaret Hassan's release after her kidnapping in Iraq.
Mrs Hassan led Care International operations in Iraq before being abducted on October 19.
Galloway was expelled from the Labour party due to his opposition to war with Iraq, but has now made a direct appeal to kidnappers via Al-Jazeera Arabic television channel.
llama3.2:3b: George Galloway appeals for the release of Margaret Hassan, a prominent anti-war activist who was kidnapped in Iraq on October 19.
Galloway denies making a direct appeal to the kidnappers and says he is willing to do anything necessary to help save her life, including going to Iraq or acting as an intermediary.
gemma2:2b: George Galloway, former Labour MP expelled for opposing the war on Iraq, is appealing for the release of Margaret Hassan, an aid worker kidnapped in Iraq.
He claims he's willing to do anything to help save her life and has connections to Ms. Hassan through shared anti-war activism.

Videos released by Al-Jazeera show Ms. Hassan's plea for British troops to leave Iraq and calls for Care International to close its office in Baghdad, leading to the agency shutting down all operations there.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Galloway expressed his desire to release Margaret Hassan, an aid worker abducted in Iraq.
He stated that he will not use any of the situations where he previously opposed the war or sanctions.
Mrs Hassan, 59, was a prominent opponent of both the war and previous years of sanctions.
She has been a prominent anti-war activist, seeking British troops to leave Iraq and demanding the closure of Care International's operations in Baghdad.
qwen2.5:1.5b: George Galloway appeals for release of Margaret Hassan, a kidnapped aid worker from Care International, who was abducted while leading operations against sanctions and opposing the war on Iraq.
qwen2.5:3b: Ex-Labour MP George Galloway has called for the release of Margaret Hassan, a 59-year-old aid worker kidnapped in Baghdad.
He denied earlier reports he planned to appeal directly to her abductors through Al-Jazeera.
Galloway expressed willingness to help save her life due to her anti-war stance and involvement with his newly-founded party, Respect Coalition.

Mrs. Hassan has been featured on several Al Jazeera videos since being abducted, urging for British troops withdrawal from Iraq, closing her agency's Baghdad office, and calling for freed Iraqi women prisoners.
opencoder:1.5b: Galloway's plea for release of hostage is a clear and straightforward appeal to the nonviolence organization that supports international peace efforts.
The case highlights how Mr Galloway struggled against the regime's opposition to the war on Iraq during the 1970s, with severe criticism of its actions.
He was expelled from the Labour party due to his resistance, but he has since made several contributions including helping free women in Iraq and appealing for humanitarian assistance.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary accurately captures the main ideas and key points from the original text:

1.
The appeal of George Galloway for the release of Margaret Hassan, a prominent anti-war activist.
The context of the kidnapping, including the location (Iraq) and the time of year (October 19).
The reason behind Mr Galloway's opposition to the war on Iraq: his staunch opposition to the war.
The key points made by Mr Galloway about Mrs Hassan, including her prominent anti-war activism and her role in Care International.
The appeal of George Galloway for the release of Margaret Hassan, with a focus on the kidnapping and the context of the event.

He denies an earlier appeal and stated willing to assist if necessary.

tinyllama:1.1b: Galloway pleads for hostage release, appeals for aid worker Margaret Hassan's relief from kidnap by Iraqi terrorists.

In a news conference held on Saturday in London, George Galloway, the leader of a newly-formed political party, announced his willingness to make a direct appeal to the kidnappers via Al-Jazeera Arabic channel.

The British MP for the Labour party expelled for his staunch opposition to the war on Iraq said he had "deliberately not involved myself before in any of these situations" and that he is prepared to do anything to help save Mrs. Hassan's life.

Speaking at the first annual delegate conference of his newly-found political party, Galloway was met with cheers by an audience which included Care International officials, Iraqi women prisoners, and members of the Respect Coalition, a new political grouping formed in Britain.

In the footage, Ms. Hassan is seen asking for British troops to be pulled out of Iraq and for Care International to close its office in Baghdad, while appealing for Iraqi women imprisoned by the terrorists to be freed.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The text is about a former Labour MP who is calling for the release of an aid worker who was kidnapped by terrorists in Iraq.

Mr Galloway, who was suspended from the Labour party due to his opposition to the war on Iraq, claimed that he will make a direct appeal to the kidnappers through the Al-Jazeera Arabic television channel.
He is not involved in previous similar situations and believes there may be another way to help save Mrs Hassan's life.

Care International has since closed down its operations in Iraq.

Since her abduction, several videos of Mrs Hassan have been broadcast by Al-Jazeera, urging Care International to close its office in Baghdad and appealing for Iraqi women prisoners to be freed.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Ex-Labour MP George Galloway, now leader of the Respect Coalition, pleaded for the release of aid worker Margaret Hassan, kidnapped in Baghdad on October 19, 2003.
Hassan, 59, led Care International's Iraq operations and was a vocal anti-war activist.
Galloway, expelled from Labour over his opposition to the Iraq war, assured he would do "anything" to help save her life.
He confirmed having common acquaintances with Hassan and expressed readiness to act as an intermediary or travel to Iraq.

Since her abduction, multiple videos of Hassan have been broadcast by Al-Jazeera, where she called for British troops' withdrawal from Iraq, the closure of Care International's Baghdad office, and the release of Iraqi women prisoners.
Care International subsequently ceased all operations in Iraq following Hassan's kidnapping.
